abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, but only modest
            institutional development impacts. Given the current
            political situation in Peru - a new government faced with a
            divided Congress - it is still too early to anticipate
            long-term lessons from the project, despite a beneficial
            participation, and project coordination (including the
            mobilization of additional resources, and real increases in
            efficiency, and sustainability of reforms). Therefore,
            implementation of the project's social reforms will
            have to overcome resistance of diverse interest groups, and
            be heavily dependent on the leadership provided by the
            Government; not so much so on the role of the Bank, whose
            ability to promote national consensus may be limited.
            Moreover, the start-up costs are likely to be particularly
            high, but such costs should be viewed rather as an
            investment, where governments, and international donors
            supporting social programs, should be prepared for a lengthy
            gestation period, willing to accept the uncertainties
            involved. In such a context, the project appears to be an
            instrument well adapted to the situation
